lines.text: Aha! Revenge mit toothpaste!
He's not in his best mood.
He's probably taken a look at my expense account.
Yes, I glanced at it too. Miscellaneous - a hundred dollars? Isn't that excessive for miscellaneous?
Not when it's a blonde.
I'll bet he's a funny looking old baboon.
How about this, then, chief? I've... a grand idea for a contest. We offer a prize to the girl with the loveliest teeth and prettiest smile.
No, what next?
Gee, Dad, I think that's a great idea.
I am not interested in contests or in your opinion, Angela.
Why not? It sounds swell!
There you are chief! That's the women's angle for you.
She knows absolutely nothing about business. No woman does.
So, it's a business woman you are, Miss Twitchell. Not just a pretty girl. Well, tell me, how did your father ever let you skip away from him?
For a long time I've asked Dad for a job at his plant. But, because I'm a woman he won't hear of it.
Little girl, have you ever been inside a Ruggles Drug Store?
Of course! Who hasn't?
Sorry, I've got the industry pretty well tied up. You better switch to ladies underwear or corsets.
Pretty sure of yourself, aren't you, Mr. O'Connor.
Oh, you wouldn't steal a poor traveling salesman's business away now, would you?
When I do, try suspenders or shoelaces.
Martini. Manhattan. Old Fashioned. Port. Gin. Sherry. Rye. Bourbon. Scotch. Bacardi. Burgundy. And sauternes. Like it, Mr. McNeill?
Mmm. Slick!
Try this. With a gargle like that, it'd be a pleasure to have a sore throat.
I shouldn't wonder but what you got something there.
I got people brushing their teeth twenty times a day.
What's holding up the parade, honey?
I've told you a dozen times, Mr. O'Connor. He's got someone in there.

Well, I know. But, they've been in there for over a half an hour, sweetheart. Couldn't you just sort of trickle in and whisper in his ear that Pat O'Connor, in person, is gettin' pretty darn tired of waitin'.
He doesn't like me to go in there when he's tied up.
Why, if I were Mr. McNeill you couldn't come in often enough, darling.
Have you been on the road long, Miss Smith?
No, this is my first trip.
Well, how about having dinner with me tonight?
I've been on the road long enough to know the answer to that! But, I will have dinner with you next trip - when I need a bigger order.
Hello Andy.
Hello, Pat. Glad to see you. So, you two know each other?
We've met; but, we don't know each other.
Boy, watch your step. She's got a line of goods that's dynamite.
I've just bought the girl's whole line. Here, look.
Don't show it to me! I know it by heart. I've read so many Cocktail Toothpaste ads I go to bed drunk every night.
I've seen 'em come and I've seen 'em go. So, gather the rose buds while you may. I'll still be selling Twitchell's when the buyers have forgotten whether Schmidt's made toothpaste or sausage casings.
There you go talking shop again. Its eight o'clock. Let's make an agreement - after eight o'clock no toothpaste talk.
Okay. From eight AM till eight PM - deadly enemies.
Okay. And from eight PM to eight AM?
Time will tell.

Hello. Isn't this a marvelous age we live in. We are both going to the same town. You're leaving at midnight and I'm leaving at nine o'clock and we're on the same train. I guess that's what Einstein meant by relativity.
Darling!
Claudette,where did you come from? Out of a crack in the wall?
No, I go lonely for you in New York. I telephoned your office and they said you were here. So, here am I...
Well, I'm sorry. Gee, I wish I'd have known. I'm all dated up.
Your dated up? With whom?
Well, eh, with the Chamber of Commerce. One of those, eh, stag affairs. Very dull.
Don't tell me I came all the way to Detroit to twiddle my thumbs.

You are, without a doubt, the most unethical, unscrupulous. conniving, sales person I've ever had the bad luck to run into. You've knifed me, you've cut my throat, you've stolen my business. Male or female, I'd like to break your neck.
Why don't you!
I'm only human. I'd kinda hate to take business away from the man I'm falling in love with.
Come here a minute. Did you say falling?
Fell.
Elmer, wouldn't you like a lovely office with a pretty secretary instead of messing around with all those things?
Oh, no. My place is with my test tubes. When I make teeth white - I will now make them glisten.
I should have known better than to ask advice of a woman!

[O'Connor calling on a pay phone]
Miss Martha Smith?
Yes, honey, this is Martha Smith. What do y'all want?
Is this Miss Martha Smith?
Yes. Dis is Martha Smith. I dun told you once, what do y'all want?
Well, I sho 'nough don't want you!
After dinner with him, what did you do?
I tried to find you.
Did you look in the phone book?
Darling, there's 4,555 and one-half Martha Smiths in New York. Started to call them, but I ran out of nickels.
You going on the Century?
No, I'm going to fly.
Oh, darling, I hate the idea of you flying. Something might happen to you.
Oh, that's absurd.
Oh, promise me you won't fly. I can't bear the thought of you in the air.
Well, honey, if you feel that way about it.
Let's meet at the train, shall we?
He's good and sore. You'll never square yourself now.
Don't you think so?
He's mad!
Oh, you'd be surprised what I can square after eight o'clock.
Listen, now, I kinda got stuck on a girl which is named Claudette. You know who I mean?
Don't tell me. Don't tell me. Let me guess.
Why can't we be palsy-walsy like?
So, you've been two-timing on me, huh! After all that toothpaste I bought from you. Well, I'm through with men from now on!
So am I! They're not to be trusted. Let's get outta here!
Wait a minute!
Gigolo!
You take care of this merger, I've got an important one of my own!
Pat! Pat!
What do you want?
I want to go to Niagara Falls.
Can you swim?
No. But, I can cook!
